comments.text:
+Michael Parker Light skin has always been part of African DNA. The San 
people are dark brown to yellow to almost beige without any influence from 
Europe. Modern Africans, however, do have European admixture that came from 
Europe, the Near East, Europe many times over (North Africa conquests and 
later the colonization of the entire continent).  The middle Eastern people 
are an amalgamation of Africans and Caucasians (who are not too 
far from the Levant, who have actually significantly whitened the Levant).

comments.author: Mitochondrial Eve

comments.text:
+Michael Parker Black skin will never become extinct or rare. That would be 
the stupidest blunder on mother nature's part. Although you never know, 
mother nature is far from perfect. But the evidence shows us that even in

http://www.encognitive.com/files/images/skin-cancer-statistics-by-country-europe.jpg
comments.author: Mitochondrial Eve

comments.text:
+Mitochondrial Eve Evolution doesn't mean things always improve, it simply 
means adapting to the environment.
And the fact is that the Humans that left Africa developed cultures less 
reliant on being a hunter gatherer and spent more time indoors in colder 
climates.
And vitamin D does come from the sun and that is why blacks have stronger 
bones because the African culture meant more time outside doing physical 
activities, and the fact is that as modern society takes over more in 
Africa their skin will lighten and Blacks will become much rarer in the 
World.
comments.author: Michael Parker

comments.text:
+Michael Parker White skin has ZERO to do with evolution. This is a planet 
that depends on a life giving sun for its very existence. Entire religions 
have been created to worship the sun and its life giving qualities. How is 
developing white skin evolutionary? That's hogwash. The polar bear has 
black skin under the white fur, the arctic fox has black skin under it's 
white fur. The Native Alaskan and Native Canadian and Native American 
tribes were/are all darker than white Europeans. What race of people is 
"turning" another color today or has "turned" anther color in the last 500 
years, or 1,000 years or so? I think it would have been documented. No such 
drivel. Only way to "turn" skin is through admixture with another race or 
some kind of unique, odd ball type of situation.

Blacks have stronger bones and more vitamin D bioavailable to us than white 
people. White supermarkets are chock full of calcium fortified and vitamin 
D fortified foods, so having light skin has done ZILCH for whites. Whites 
and Asians (the lightest people on earth) have the highest incidents of 
osteoporosis (brittle bones).  My parents grew up in a Caribbean country 
with no fortified foods and have super strong bones and good health. The 
bulk of the country folks in my country are super strong, hardy, wiry folks 
who can eat four plantains, three fried eggs with onions and a whole milk 
shake with sugar for breakfast and still be thin as rails and strong as 
oxen. The proof is ALL AROUND US....whites are the weakest race and blacks 
are the strongest.
comments.author: Mitochondrial Eve

comments.text:
+Mitochondrial Eve Whites are white because they left Africa into colder 
climates and advancements meant less reason to be outside, so just evolved 
not to need the sun protection that black skin gives you.
comments.author: Michael Parker

comments.text:

comments.author: Gyissan

top_comment.text:
Albinism = body either can't produce the protein melanin, that causes skin 
pigmentation. Or body is insensitive to melanin (receptors don't work 
properly). So all normally pigmented cells remain un-pigmented. This is 
caused by a genetic mutation, I think either a substitution or deletion of 
one of the nucleotides of the DNA that make up the gene transcribed for 
melanin protein. So it's not a curse, or a disease!﻿

comments.text:
No honey, we all came from Africa. But as we spread out across the globe 
our bodies changed and developed according to our surroundings. Most white 
people come from areas where there isn't a lot of hot sunlight such as 
Northern Europe and closer to the northern and southern poles. Even Asians 
developed light skin because they didn't need the strong influence of 
melanin, which is what colors dark skin. Also the texture of our hair, our 
eye shape, nose shape, lash length, skin texture, and many other 
characteristics are the product of our bodies changing so that we could 
better survive in areas that we settled in and began to reproduce. It's all 
evolution, that's all :) There are white albino's as well. But there is 
actually no such thing as race, we are all classified as part of the 
greater ape species called homosapiens. We are not classified as to our 
skin color because our genetic makeup is the same strand for all humans. 
Race is a social construct that I do not recognize because it is 
unnecessary.

captions.text:
00:07
COMM: Meet the Andrade kids. Who are used

to stares wherever they go. Unlike their brothers
and sisters, siblings Ruth, Estefani and Kauan

were born with albinism. and their condition
doesn't just affect the way they look. It

poses a number of challenges for the family
and a major health warning awaits them.

00:27
COMM: Mum Rosamere from Recife, Brazil was

shocked when first daughter Ruth was born.
Rosamere was even more convinced there had

been a mix up when second child Joao Paulo
was born black.

00:46
COMM: Estefani was third followed by Kauan,

then Rebecca and finally Maria, while Rosamere
is proud of her family some of the local community
think
they are cursed.

01:18
COMM: At school the children face other challenges,

their condition causes poor eyesight so they
struggle to see the board
in lessons.

01:46
COMM: On hot days the albino children have
to shelter from the sun's dazzling rays.

01:57
COMM: Rosamere and step-father Robenilson,

who has not fathered any of the Albinos worries
that the condition makes life to difficult
for them.

02:13
COMM: To find out more they have arranged

to see dermatologist Sergio Paulo who shockingly
reveals the children are at a high risk of

melanomas
and other types of skin cancer.

02:58
COMM: Armed with new knowledge Rosamere feels

she can continue to give her kids normal lives,
while helping to protect them in better ways.

title: My Albino Children: Black Brazilian Family Have Three White-Skinned Children
